title: Welcome
text: Hello, I’m Mo Wang, a first year ScM Biostatistics student. I am from China and finished my undergrad in the UK. The photo attached is Daniel Lozakovich with London Philharmonic Orchestra. Daniel is my favorite violinist, he is elegant and charming.

title: About Me
text:
I completed my BSc in Statistics at UCL (University College London), where I found an open, kind community， and plenty of chances to take day trips to towns around London.
In my free time I do pilates, play golf and bake
I also love to travel, when I was in the UK I visited Spain every vacation.
I’m a huge fan of classical music (let’s go to a concert!).
Favorites: Sergei Rachmaninoff (composer), Daniil Trifonov (pianist) and Daniel Lozakovich (violinist).
Now in my first year at JHU Biostatistics, I’m exploring widely, with growing interests in spatial data and causal inference.

Fun facts

Best day trip near London: Winchester.
Comfort bake: Matcha cheesecake.

title: Example analysis: Iris Dataset
text:
Note



Question
How do the Iris’s sepal and petal differ across the three iris species?
Data source
The iris dataset is already built in base R. It contains measurements of sepal length, sepal width, petal length, and petal width for 150 iris flowers across species: setosa, versicolor, and virginica.
- Data documentation: https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/datasets/html/iris.html

title: Example analysis: Iris Dataset
text:
Data dictionary for iris

Data dictionary for the iris dataset used in this analysis.


Variable
Description




sepal.length
Length of the sepal (cm)


sepal.width
Width of the sepal (cm)


petal.length
Length of the petal (cm)


petal.width
Width of the petal (cm)


species
Iris species (setosa, versicolor, virginica)

title: Example analysis: Iris Dataset
text:
Load and wrangle data

library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Clean + wrangle iris data
# Clean data
iris_full <- iris |>
  rename_with(tolower) |>
  rename_with(~ gsub("\\.", "_", .x)) |>
  mutate(
    species = as.factor(species),
    ratio   = petal_length / sepal_length
  ) |>
  filter(sepal_length > 4)


# A separate summary table
iris_summary <- iris_full |>
  group_by(species) |>
  summarise(
    mean_sepal_length  = mean(sepal_length),
    mean_petal_length  = mean(petal_length),
    mean_ratio         = mean(ratio),
    n                  = dplyr::n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# View cleaned summary
head(iris_summary)

# A tibble: 3 × 5
  species    mean_sepal_length mean_petal_length mean_ratio     n
  <fct>                  <dbl>             <dbl>      <dbl> <int>
1 setosa                  5.01              1.46      0.293    50
2 versicolor              5.94              4.26      0.718    50
3 virginica               6.59              5.55      0.844    50

title: Example analysis: Iris Dataset
text:
Three Plots

## Three plots

# Plot 1
ggplot(iris_full, aes(sepal_length, petal_length, color = species)) +
geom_point(size = 2) +
geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
labs(
title = "Petal vs Sepal Length by Species",
subtitle = "Linear trends show differences among species",
x = "Sepal Length (cm)",
y = "Petal Length (cm)",
color = "Species"
)







# Plot 2
ggplot(iris_full, aes(species, sepal_width, fill = species)) +
geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.6) +
facet_wrap(~ species) +
labs(
title = "Distribution of Sepal Width by Species",
subtitle = "Setosa has the largest median sepal width; Versicolor and Virginica show narrower distributions",
x = "Species", y = "Sepal Width (cm)"
)







#Plot 3
ggplot(iris_full, aes(petal_width, fill = species)) +
geom_density(alpha = 0.4) +
labs(
title = "Distribution of Petal Width across Species",
subtitle = "Setosa petals are much thinner than the other two species; Virginica shows the widest spread",
x = "Petal Width (cm)", y = "Density"
)








Summary of results Setosa flowers are clearly smaller, with short petals and wide sepals.
Virginica flowers tend to be the largest across all dimensions.
Versicolor serves as a middle group, overlapping partially with the other two.
Linear trends suggest strong correlations between petal and sepal measurements.
The density plots show clean species separation, which is why iris is often used for classification.
Functions used
From dplyr/tidyr (Wickham et al. 2023): rename_with(), mutate(), filter(), group_by(), summarise(), across()
From ggplot2 (Wickham 2016): geom_point(), geom_smooth(), geom_boxplot(), geom_density(), facet_wrap(), labs()
